p: Even though the incidence of pediatric diarrheal diseases is declining worldwide, they remain the second most common cause of preventable illness and death among children under the age of five [ 1], responsible for approximately 800 million illnesses and 800,000 deaths in 2010. Approximately 90% of this disease burden is concentrated in children under the age of five in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) [ 2, 3]. Diarrheal infections are caused by a diverse range of enteric pathogens that infect children as early as birth [ 4]. Children infected with enteric pathogens can potentially suffer long-term adverse effects to their physical and cognitive development and future socio-economic status [ 5, 6].
